What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I can understand and communicate with basic German.

I developed a basic set of communication skills in German. I learned the importance of the German language in today's world, and I started seeing how it can be helpful for a future career. I got to learn a little bit about the culture in German-speaking countries (Germany, Austria, and Switzerland in particular).
Introductory German speaking, reading, and writing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is very thorough and definitely provides you with a good understanding of German language and grammar. I definitely feel like I understand the grammatical concepts we learned, as opposed to just memorizing them for the exams. I also feel like this course allowed us to practice reading, writing, speaking, and understanding German--it was very well rounded. Sometimes the course felt like it was moving very quickly. I wish we had a bit more time to review material that we learned independently in the homework or asynchronous classwork.

The MAJOR strength of this course is the section lecturers. Liese Sippel and Ido Ben Harush are incredibly patient and considerate towards the students, which makes for incredibly entertaining live virtual sessions (notice that I am saying having just A1 fluency in German). The grading is adequate for an introductory language class, where it is expected that students will make occasional mistakes. Indeed, this encourages students to go beyond the Wortschatz (vocabulary in the textbook) and try new structures and vocabulary without being penalized for doing so wrongly. 

Feedback was always very clear, and the instructors are willing to stay some minutes after class to answer some questions.

The only weakness that I would note is the uneven workload across the semester in terms of activities on asynchronous days. Some days it would take 20 minutes to finish, but others it could take up to 2-3 hours.
The workload assigned on asynchronous days far exceeded the number of hours of work on a synchronous day and throughout the semester it seemed like that amount of work only increased.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, I thought the course ran very smoothly in the online format. I thought the use of breakout rooms worked very well and allowed us to practice our German in smaller groups. Although we could not practice speaking German in person, there were a lot of opportunities to practice our spoken German using online recordings. One aspect of the course that could be improved is the asynchronous work; it was sometimes confusing and a bit overwhelming.

The Zoom live sessions were definitely the highlight of the semester. I would suggest that the German Department replace the asynchronous component of the class with a synchronous component, so that workload can be more predictable. As an alternative to keep the asynchronous component, I would highly recommend revising the length of those assignments to make them more even.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student interested in learning German. The course is structured very well and is very conducive to learning. However, I would warn the student that the course is a lot of work and requires a lot of time.

I would definitely recommend it! *Especially* if it's being taught by Liese Sippel and Ido Ben Harush. You will learn a lot of German in just one semester in a relatively low-pressure environment, where the focus is on learning a language as opposed to mastering a vocabulary sheet.
